text:
Minimum quality criteria These criteria summarize minimum acceptable ultrasound image quality for common POCUS views, adapted from expert consensus and practice standards. They are intended to explain why an image may be nondiagnostic.

Cardiac views (POCUS)
Parasternal long‑axis (PLAX)

Minimum quality criteria – PLAX (heart)

Depth includes the descending thoracic aorta but avoids excessive empty far field.

Gain produces a balanced gray‑scale image in both near and far field, with blood in all chambers appearing anechoic.

Beam is aligned with the long axis of the left ventricle so that the LV cavity appears at maximal length.

Required structures: aortic valve near midline, mitral valve roughly centered, RV outflow tract, LV cavity (apex often not seen), and left atrium all visible.
​

Parasternal short‑axis – aortic valve level

Minimum quality criteria – PSAX AV level (heart)

Depth includes the inferior wall of the left atrium without unnecessary far‑field depth.

Gain is balanced in near and far field.

Beam is centered over the aortic valve so that AV leaflets plus right atrium, right ventricle, and left atrium are all seen.

Required structures: three AV cusps (right, non‑coronary, left), plus LA, interatrial septum, RA, tricuspid valve, and RV.
​

Parasternal short‑axis – mitral and papillary levels

Minimum quality criteria – PSAX MV level (heart)

LV on screen right; RV on left or center.

Depth is just enough to include the inferior LV wall.

Gain is balanced in near and far field.

Beam passes through the mitral valve; oblique planes that distort the LV into an oval shape are avoided.

Required structures: both mitral leaflets, septum, RV, and endocardium of all LV walls clearly seen.
​

Minimum quality criteria – PSAX mid‑papillary level (heart)

LV on screen right; RV on left or center.

Depth sufficient to include inferior LV wall without extra far field.

Gain balanced in near and far field.

Beam through papillary muscles in a true short‑axis; MV not seen and LV not oval.

Required structures: two papillary muscles symmetric, septum and RV visible, LV endocardium visible all around.
​

Parasternal short‑axis – apical level

Minimum quality criteria – PSAX apical level (heart)

LV centered on screen.

Depth sufficient to include inferior LV wall, avoiding excessive depth.

Gain balanced in near and far field.

Beam aligned over the apex so papillary muscles are not seen and LV is not foreshortened or oval.

Required structures: LV endocardium visible circumferentially.
​

Apical four‑chamber

Minimum quality criteria – A4C (heart)

Orientation: RA/RV on screen left; LA/LV on screen right.

Depth deep enough to include the full extent of both atria.

Gain balanced in near and far field.

Imaging plane: apex centered, interventricular septum vertically oriented, ventricles elongated with LV oval and RV triangular.

Required structures: lateral walls of LV and RV visible, TV and MV well visualized with valves at maximal chamber diameter, and all four chambers identifiable; coronary sinus and aortic root should not appear in a proper A4C view.
​

Subcostal four‑chamber and IVC

Minimum quality criteria – subcostal 4‑chamber (heart)

Orientation: atria (base of heart) on screen left; ventricles on right.

Depth sufficient to include inferolateral LA wall.

Gain balanced in near and far field.

All four chambers clearly seen; aortic valve/root absent; LV and RV elongated (LV oval, RV triangular).

Required structures: TV, MV, LV, RV, RA, LA; liver and diaphragm usually visible in the near field.
​

Minimum quality criteria – IVC long‑axis (heart/IVC)

RA and diaphragm on the indicator side; indicator directed cephalad.

Depth deep enough to keep the IVC centered in the image.

Gain balanced in near and far field.

Beam aligned with IVC longitudinally so anterior and posterior walls appear as parallel, thin echogenic lines; IVC–RA junction is seen.

Required structures: IVC in long axis, hepatic vein (if visible), liver and diaphragm.
​

Lung views
Normal lung with A‑lines

Minimum quality criteria – normal lung (A‑lines)

Depth typically at least 10–12 cm and sufficient to visualize more than two A‑lines.

Gain balanced across near and far field.

Beam perpendicular to the pleural line; orientation cephalo‑caudad with rib shadows on one or both sides.

Required structures: thin, crisp pleural line; ≥2 clear A‑lines; ribs and rib shadows visible.
​

B‑lines

Minimum quality criteria – B‑lines

Gain balanced in near and far field.

Beam perpendicular to pleural line; longitudinal orientation with rib shadows at one or both lateral edges.

Required structures: pleural line; clear B‑lines meeting standard definition; ribs and rib shadows.
​

Consolidation / hepatization

Minimum quality criteria – lung consolidation/hepatization

Depth sufficient to show the full extent of the consolidated area.

Gain balanced in near and far field.

Beam perpendicular to pleural line with rib shadows bordering one or both sides; indicator side cephalad.

Required structures: pleural line, obvious consolidated/hepatized lung, ribs and rib shadows.
​

Pleural effusion

Minimum quality criteria – pleural effusion

Depth deep enough to visualize the spine and estimate effusion size.

Gain balanced in near and far field.

Beam perpendicular to chest wall; longitudinal orientation with lung, diaphragm, and effusion all visible.

Required structures: pleural effusion, lung parenchyma (unless effusion spans multiple interspaces), diaphragm, and spine (when scanned laterally).
​

Abdomen (example kidney + aorta + bladder)
Right kidney with hepatorenal recess (longitudinal)

Minimum quality criteria – right kidney longitudinal (abdomen)

Depth includes entire kidney centered on screen.

Gain balanced near and far field.

Beam aligned longitudinally through the hilum; both superior and inferior poles shown by rocking/sliding; kidney appears oval, not circular, and is oriented along the rib spaces to reduce shadowing.

Required structures: renal cortex and pelvis (vessels often visible but not mandatory), both poles of the kidney, and part of the hepatorenal recess plus adjacent liver.
​

Right kidney transverse

Minimum quality criteria – right kidney transverse (abdomen)

Depth sufficient to center the kidney in the image.

Gain balanced near and far field.

Beam transverse through the renal hilum so hilar vessels and collecting system are visible.

Required structures: kidney in transverse section with poles demonstrated by fanning/tilting.
​

Abdominal aorta (transverse and longitudinal)

Minimum quality criteria – abdominal aorta transverse (abdomen)

Depth adequate to visualize the vertebral shadow.

Gain balanced near and far field.

Beam perpendicular to the aorta; circular aorta centered with clearly seen anterior and posterior walls.

Required structures: proximal aorta with celiac or SMA branches, IVC, and vertebral shadow; diameter measured at widest points for proximal, mid, and distal segments according to local protocol.
​

Minimum quality criteria – abdominal aorta longitudinal (abdomen)

Depth sufficient for vertebral shadow.

Gain balanced near and far field.

Beam aligned along aortic long axis so both walls run across the screen without narrowing or cut‑off; oblique “beak” views are avoided.

Required structures: aorta in long axis (proximal/mid/distal), spine, and at least two branches (e.g., celiac trunk and SMA).
​

Urinary bladder (transverse and longitudinal)

Minimum quality criteria – bladder transverse (abdomen)

Depth deep enough to see the entire posterior bladder wall and pelvic organs (rectum and prostate or uterus).

Gain balanced in near/far field with far‑field gain adjusted to reduce posterior enhancement.

Beam centered transversely over bladder capturing maximal transverse dimensions.

Required structures: bladder in transverse plane plus pelvic organs in the far field.
​

Minimum quality criteria – bladder longitudinal (abdomen)

Depth deep enough to include posterior bladder wall and pelvic organs.

Gain balanced near and far field.

Beam centered longitudinally over the bladder to capture maximal length; probe typically at superior posterior margin of pubic symphysis and rocked toward pelvis.

Required structures: bladder in long axis, pelvic organs in far field, and symphysis pubis plus its acoustic shadow when the bladder is not massively distended.
